current_fact.fact_text: In 1969, American aquanaut Berry L. Cannon died from carbon dioxide poisoning while trying to repair a leak in SEALAB III, an experimental underwater habitat. His death abruptly halted the U.S. Navy’s bold attempt to turn the ocean floor into a place where humans could live and work for weeks at a time.

queue.fact_text: Back in 1674, a powerful earthquake struck near Ambon Island in Indonesia and triggered a megatsunami whose wave is estimated to have reached about 100 meters in height. The wall of water swept far inland, drowning over 2,300 people and leaving a stark historical record of just how extreme tsunami events can be.

episode.title: Morning Drops #45 - It Can't Rain Forever
episode.description:
In this first broadcast of 2026, Gaia returns from the vivid landscapes of Morocco to open a space for reflection. This episode navigates the delicate transition between closing a significant chapter and stepping into the new year. It explores the concept of constancy amidst change, celebrating the grounding force of friendship and the creative sanctuary that is Sedna FM.

The musical selection mirrors this journey, moving from the orchestral depth of changing seasons into the golden warmth of psychedelic soul. It recalls memories of Swiss mountains and unexpected downpours, reminding us that shared optimism can weather any storm.

Take a moment to breathe in the new morning and listen deeply.

Mood: Reflective, Warm, Transitional, Hopeful
Music genre: Classic Rock, Psychedelic Soul, Pop Rock, Soft Rock

queue.match_reason: A devastating megatsunami and an episode about storms, rain, and resilience both explore nature’s force and the human need to find hope afterward.

queue.fact_text: In 1944, the U.S. Navy launched Operation Hailstone, a massive two‑day air, surface, and submarine assault on Truk Lagoon, Japan’s main Pacific stronghold. The attack sank so many ships and planes that today the lagoon is one of the world’s most haunting underwater graveyards and a famous diving site.

episode.title: Morning Drops #31 - Sailing With Germans
episode.description: From the deck of a sailing boat, hosted by Yasmin and her special guests. A week at sea with six Germans, each with their own stories, songs, and ways of moving through the waves. From shared meals to unexpected laughter, from quiet resilience to sun-soaked joy — a collection of voices and tracks that reflect what it means to journey together.
songs: Ben Howard - Keep Your Head Up

queue.match_reason: A naval onslaught turning a lagoon into a ship graveyard contrasts poignantly with a gentle sea‑voyage episode, both bound by the ocean and ships.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 1864, the Confederate submarine H. L. Hunley became the first submarine in history to sink an enemy warship when it attacked the USS Housatonic. The breakthrough came at a terrible price: Hunley itself was lost with all eight crew members, and its wreck remained buried in the seafloor for over a century.

episode.title: Sedna FM #01 - November Bomb
episode.description: The first Family & Friends radio episode from Yasmin Sarbaoui and Gaia Parolini. Where it all began — a life soundtrack that launched Sedna FM into the universe. Raw, heartfelt, and full of the energy that defines everything that followed.

queue.fact_text: In 1676, an expedition led by Pascual de Iriate lost sixteen men at the remote Evangelistas Islets, jagged rocks at the storm‑wracked western mouth of the Strait of Magellan. Their disappearance in dangerous, foggy waters earned those islets a grim reputation among sailors navigating the edge of South America.

episode.title: Morning Drops #39 - Moving Meditation
episode.description: An episode inspired by how travel helps us see more clearly. Stepping into new places opens the mind, shifts perspective. The music moves through balearic warmth, boogie grooves, world and latin-folk influences, and touches of new wave — a selection built to follow the quiet changes that happen when you're out of your usual rhythm.

queue.match_reason: A perilous seafaring expedition at the world’s edge reflects the theme of travel, perspective shifts, and journeys into unfamiliar places.

queue.fact_text: In 1996, world chess champion Garry Kasparov defeated IBM’s Deep Blue in a six‑game match in Philadelphia, briefly reaffirming human dominance in a battle billed as man versus machine. The computer would win the rematch the next year, but this first encounter became a symbol of our uneasy dance with artificial intelligence.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. A dive into the psychology of our relationship with smartphones: from nomophobia (the fear of being without a phone), to digital burnout and cognitive overload, to the surprising benefits of boredom and the brain's default mode network. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

queue.match_reason: A human–computer chess showdown pairs naturally with an episode that examines our psychological entanglement with digital technology and machines.

queue.fact_text: Also in 1944, U.S. forces began the Battle of Eniwetok in the Marshall Islands, a brutal struggle for a tiny atoll that took just five days to change control of a vast stretch of the Pacific. The coral islands became a launching point for later nuclear tests, leaving the lagoon with a complex legacy of war and science.

episode.title: Morning Drops #35 - Thailand
episode.description: Recorded in Koh Samui, Thailand, where Yasmin and her friend Patricia spent more than two intense weeks training Muay Thai and Western boxing. queue.fact_text: In 1859, French naval forces captured the Citadel of Saigon, a star‑shaped fortress defending the Nguyen dynasty’s control over southern Vietnam. The fall of this bastion marked a turning point that would lead to decades of French colonial rule in the region they called Cochinchina.

episode.title: Morning Drops #11 - Mediterranean Boat
episode.description: Gaia invites you to embark on a musical voyage across the Mediterranean. Exploring music from different countries shared by people who call them home. A warm, sun-soaked journey through coastal sounds.

queue.match_reason: A French naval fortress in Asia echoes with an episode built around seas, coasts, and the cultural ripples of maritime powers like France around the world.

queue.fact_text: In 1995, Peru and Ecuador ended the brief but intense Cenepa War with a UN‑brokered ceasefire after weeks of jungle combat over a stretch of remote, disputed border. The conflict was fought in rugged, cloud‑forested terrain so inaccessible that helicopters and mountain troops often decided the fate of the ridgelines.

episode.title: Morning Drops #16 - The Sound of Tuareg
episode.description: A journey into the sound of the Tuareg: from traditional chants and desert rituals to the electrified rhythms of exile and resistance. Music shaped by sand, memory, and survival.

queue.match_reason: A border war in harsh, remote terrain parallels Tuareg music born from borderlands, exile, and armed resistance in another rugged part of the world.

queue.fact_text: On this date in 1753, Sweden performed a calendar ‘jump’ so dramatic that February 17 was immediately followed by March 1, skipping eleven days overnight. The country was switching from the Julian to the more accurate Gregorian calendar, effectively editing time itself to catch up with the rest of Europe.

episode.title: Morning Drops #19 - Wabi Sabi
episode.description: Wabi-sabi is a story about a handmade mug, a small mistake, and the idea that imperfection can be something to keep—not correct. In this Morning Drop, Gaia shares a moment that didn’t go to plan, and four tracks that echo the same spirit: rough takes, studio accidents, lo-fi textures, and quiet surprises. A soft, thoughtful selection moving between warm electronics, classic riffs, and raw edges.A reminder that not everything needs to be polished. Sometimes, it’s better that way.

queue.match_reason: A nation ‘correcting’ its calendar by brutally skipping days pairs with an episode about embracing imperfection rather than over‑editing time and life.

queue.fact_text: In 1500, peasant militias from the marshy region of Dithmarschen in northern Europe repelled an invasion by Duke Frederick of Schleswig-Holstein and King John of Denmark at the Battle of Hemmingstedt. Using flooded fields, dykes, and local knowledge, farmers defeated knights and nobles in one of history’s most remarkable underdog victories.

episode.title: Morning Drops #08 - (un)Boxing
episode.description: An episode about breaking free from expectations and labels. Music that helps us unbox ourselves and embrace who we truly are.

queue.fact_text: In 1814, during the War of the Sixth Coalition, Napoleon won the Battle of Mormant in France by striking a divided Russian–Prussian force with rapid, concentrated attacks. The victory was fleeting: despite tactical brilliance, the coalition’s sheer numbers would soon push him toward abdication.

episode.title: Morning Drops #36 - Women of Rock
episode.description: A tribute to the women who shaped the sound of rock, the ones who picked up a guitar and refused to ask for permission. The conversation unfolds in Italian, led by Gaia and her father. A dialogue between generations and a reminder that the pulse of rock has always belonged to anyone brave enough to play it loud. Distortion, rhythm, freedom.
songs: Joan Jett & The Blackhearts - I Love Rock 'n Roll

queue.fact_text: On this day in 1978, the Provisional IRA detonated an incendiary device at the La Mon restaurant near Belfast, killing 12 and injuring about 30 people in one of the Troubles’ most horrific attacks. The fire spread so fast that some survivors described the building as a ‘human torch’ within seconds.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.

queue.match_reason: A brutal act of violence contrasted with an episode about patient growth and learning subtly invites listeners to imagine different paths for anger and conflict.

queue.fact_text: In 1913, the Armory Show opened in New York City, shocking American audiences with radical European modernist works by artists like Picasso, Duchamp, and Matisse. Many critics mocked the show, but it quietly rewired the trajectory of American art, proving that new ways of seeing could be just as real as old ones.

queue.fact_text: In 2015, a Mardi Gras parade in Port-au-Prince, Haiti turned tragic when a power line was struck by a carnival float, triggering a panic and stampede that killed 18 people and injured dozens more. The incident revealed how fragile large celebrations can be when electrified spectacle and dense crowds collide.

episode.title: Morning Drops #12 - 80's Club
episode.description: Starting with a Monday evening in Munich — a few drinks, friends, and landing in an 80s dance party. From Donna Summer's hypnotic pulse, to Depeche Mode's bright synthpop, Ken Laszlo's Italo Disco romance, and Mylène Farmer's darker theatrical world. Four songs, four corners of the 80s — connected by the machines that changed how we dance.

queue.match_reason: A carnival disaster at a night parade links with a clubbing-themed episode where lights, crowds, and electronic dance culture are central characters.

queue.fact_text: NASA’s Discovery Program, inaugurated with NEAR Shoemaker’s 1996 launch, was designed to send smaller, cheaper missions to explore specific questions about our solar system. Instead of a few giant flagships, the program embraced a fleet of focused probes—each one a scientific ‘mixtape’ to a single destination.

queue.fact_text: The SEALAB project, abandoned after Berry Cannon’s death, had earlier shown that aquanauts could live for weeks under pressure on the seafloor, adapting their bodies to an alien environment. It hinted that ‘inner space’—our own oceans—could be explored with the same settlement mindset once reserved for outer space.

queue.fact_text: The 1913 Armory Show didn’t just display paintings—it introduced Americans to radical ideas like multiple viewpoints in Cubism and the abstraction of pure color and form. Viewers reportedly laughed, fumed, and argued in front of the works, proving that confusion can be the first step toward a new visual language.

queue.fact_text: The 1995 ceasefire that ended the Cenepa War eventually led to a definitive peace agreement five years later, turning a deadly border zone into a symbol of compromise between Peru and Ecuador. The former battlefield is now partially protected rainforest, where trees and clouds have reclaimed the ridgelines once contested by soldiers.

episode.title: Morning Drops #24 - The Rise Of Afrobeat
episode.description: An exploration of the rise of Afrobeat, tracing its roots and evolution as a genre that blends African rhythms with jazz, funk, and highlife. A celebration of the infectious energy and cultural significance of this influential musical movement.

queue.match_reason: A shift from conflict to shared agreement parallels Afrobeat’s role as a politically charged yet unifying groove, turning struggle into communal rhythm.

published.fact_text: In 1996, NASA's NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft became the first mission ever launched with the goal of orbiting and landing on an asteroid—433 Eros—turning a tiny moving rock into a whole new kind of destination. The mission showed that even small bodies in our solar system hold clues to planetary formation and the early chemistry that shaped worlds.

episode.title: Sedna FM #02 - Destination Sedna

published.fact_text: On this day in 1965, NASA’s Ranger 8 probe launched toward the Moon with one dramatic objective: to crash into the Mare Tranquillitatis after sending back thousands of high-resolution photos. Those impact‑time images helped mission planners choose the exact spot where Apollo 11 would later make humanity’s first lunar landing.

episode.title: Morning Drops #03 - Space Shift
episode.description: Gaia invites you to shift your mindset with a simple yet powerful reflection: What if we saw emptiness not as a void but as space to create? An energising and feel-good selection of tracks, the perfect way to ease into your day and set the tone for the week ahead.

published.fact_text: In 1959, Vanguard 2 became the world’s first weather satellite, carrying tiny optical scanners designed to map Earth’s cloud cover from orbit. Though its measurements were imperfect, it proved that watching the planet’s atmosphere from space could transform forecasting and our understanding of global weather patterns.

episode.title: Morning Drops #05 - Electric Shock
episode.description: An energizing episode with electrifying sounds to wake you up and get you moving. High energy tracks that deliver a jolt of musical electricity to start your day.

published.match_reason: A pioneering satellite powered by electronics and beaming data to Earth fits the high-voltage, electric-guitar atmosphere of this ‘Electric Shock’ episode.

published.fact_text: In 1996, an 8.2 magnitude earthquake struck near Biak Island in Papua, Indonesia, unleashing a powerful tsunami that swept away entire coastal villages. Locals reported that the sea retreated so far that fish flopped on bare seafloor moments before the towering waves returned.

episode.title: Morning Drops #40 - Diving With Orcas
episode.description: Yasmin's friend Caroline takes us beyond the polar circle, into the Arctic waters of Norway, where orcas and humpback whales gather each winter. A personal journey shaped by a quiet obsession with orcas, from Patagonia to the icy fjords of the north. The soundscape moves gently between cinematic swells and soft, rhythmic pulses — echoing the cold light of Arctic mornings and the grace of underwater encounters.

published.match_reason: Both the Biak tsunami and the orca-diving story center on the power and vulnerability of the ocean, calling for a contemplative, cinematic soundtrack.

published.fact_text: On this day in 1980, Polish climbers Krzysztof Wielicki and Leszek Cichy completed the first winter ascent of Mount Everest, reaching the summit in -40°C winds and thin, turbulent air. Their climb opened a new era of high‑altitude exploration where winter itself became the ultimate obstacle.
